Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

Your points seems to be that you can make it work without knowing how it wo=
rks.=C2=A0 So we need to talk about what you mean by that.

When you use th=
e microphone, you just speak, and let the recorder do the rest.=C2=A0 In th=
is case, you are using the recorder without really knowing how it works. =
=C2=A0 If a spirit can manipulate the EMF field around the AtoD converter (=
even without using the mic), then they should be able to do the same: just =
use it without knowing how it works: the recorder does the rest.=C2=A0 In n=
either case do either of you need to know how it works, to get it to work. =
I am not questioning this.

But, if they are going to change the bits on th=
e actual media themselves, then they must know how it works, it order to ge=
t all those bit-things I mentioned right.=C2=A0 The recorder can't "do the =
rest", because by changing the bits on the media themselves, they are going=
 completely around what the recorder does, and doing the details themselves=
.=C2=A0 And as I said, the details there are very technical, and include th=
ings like converting their words into digital samples of groups of a specif=
ic number of bits in a specific format on specific places in specific order=
s with other specific other bits connected to them like file ownership and =
dates and such.=C2=A0 It is the job, basically, of a computer, not a person=
.

If they are changing the bits on the media, then the recorder is not doi=
ng that.=C2=A0 They are no longer letting the recorder "do it", like you or=
 they would be if they just used it normally.=C2=A0 The reason you can "mak=
e it work" without understanding it, is because the recorder is doing the w=
ork for you.=C2=A0 If they are to change the media directly, then the recor=
der is no longer doing the work, and so they must understand all those digi=
tal issues.

So that is the difference between being able to use it without=
 understanding it, and not being able to use it.

record by messing with the =

need to delve deeper int=
o the digital world: what worked for the analog tape 
recorder, still works=
 for the digital recorder, so why all the mindboggling 
extra effort for th=
e same result?"
=C2=A0
That's what I'm sayin' LOL! They wouldn't 
need know=
 and it would still work.
=C2=A0
=C2=A0
"Maybe it's that you don't know how=

really doesn't just dump a lot of "dig=

an analog tape recorder does to=
 tape.=C2=A0 To record digitally takes many 
levels of processing, and a lo=
t of careful digital choreography on the final 
media.=C2=A0"

I=C2=

again, I don't have to know and it st=
ill works. I don't even know how exactly an 
analog recorder works either. =
I have no clue how my voice can be transferred and 
recorded via electronic=
 means. But again, I don't need to know to make it 
work.
=C2=A0
=C2=A0

Bu=
t I see what you are saying and=C2=A0this 
does make sense:

uch more credible for the signal to be manipulated near the AtoD 
converter=
 (where EMF changes would have the most straighforward result) than in 
the=
 digital media itself."

I never meant to insinuate exactly how it 
c=
ould or couldn't work, only that true EVP is not created via sound waves in=
 the 
environment. It has to be electromagnetically generated.=C2=A0From th=
is 
statement is seems=C2=A0that's entirely verifiable.

 found on analog recordings.

dia?

Manipulat=
ing EMF is one thing.=C2=A0 But 
                  directly storing bits on=
 a media is way beyond that.=C2=A0 
                  Bits are not stored i=
n a continuous stream.=C2=A0 They are 
                  broken into bytes =
(little packets) that is totally controlled 
                  by the proce=
ssor and software.=C2=A0 For Elvis to "encode 
                  directly" =
to the media, he would have to do what that software 
                  doe=
s to the digital signals coming in from the AtoD converter: 
              =
    he would have to group the bits into (for example) 16 little 
         =
         herds each, decide on the specific bit interpretation scheme 
    =
              (2's complement?) ,=C2=A0 find space on the media, update the=
 
                  media's dictionary of where there is free space and whe=
re 
                  there isn't, link the herds together with some sort o=
f linked 
                  pointer, skip around the areas marked 'bad' on =
the media, 
                  update things like date/time modified and siz=
e, respect any 
                  kind of ownership permissions on the medi=
a, and so 
                  on.

It is much more credible for the signal t=
o be 
                  manipulated near the AtoD converter (where EMF chan=
ges would 
                  have the most straighforward result) than in t=
he digital media 
                  itself.

<table cellspacing=3D"0" cellpadding=3D"0" border=3D"0" ><tr><td valign=3D"=
top" style=3D"font: inherit;">Your points seems to be that you can make it =
work without knowing how it works.  So we need to talk about what you =
mean by that.<br><br>When you use the microphone, you just speak, and let t=
he recorder do the rest.  In this case, you are using the recorder wit=
hout really knowing how it works.   If a spirit can manipulate the EMF=
 field around the AtoD converter (even without using the mic), then they sh=
ould be able to do the same: just use it without knowing how it works: the =
recorder does the rest.  In neither case do either of you need to know=
 how it works, to get it to work. I am not questioning this.<br><br>But, if=
 they are going to change the bits on the actual media themselves, then the=
y must know how it works, it order to get all those bit-things I mentioned =
right.  The recorder can't "do the rest", because by changing the bits=
 on
 the media themselves, they are going completely around what the record=
er does, and doing the details themselves.  And as I said, the details=
 there are very technical, and include things like converting their words i=
nto digital samples of groups of a specific number of bits in a specific fo=
rmat on specific places in specific orders with other specific other bits c=
onnected to them like file ownership and dates and such.  It is the jo=
b, basically, of a computer, not a person.<br><br>If they are changing the =
bits on the media, then the recorder is not doing that.  They are no l=
onger letting the recorder "do it", like you or they would be if they just =
used it normally.  The reason you can "make it work" without understan=
ding it, is because the recorder is doing the work for you.  If they a=
re to change the media directly, then the recorder is no longer doing the w=
ork, and so they must understand all those digital issues.<br><br>So
 that =
is the difference between being able to use it without understanding it, an=
d not being able to use it.<br><br><br><br>--- On <b>Wed, 5/20/09, April Ab=
ercrombie <i><april@...></i></b> wrote:<br><=

heme

ce and where

ome sort of linked

 'bad' on the media,

ed and size, respect any

n the media, and so
